AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below) Game Name: The Testament of Sherlock Holmes Original Release: 2012 Genre Tags: Adventure; Point & Click; Puzzle; Detective; Casual My Overall Grade: A- Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 10-18 hours Multiplayer Aspect: None Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Casual gamers REVIEWThe Testament of Sherlock Holmes is a very pleasantly surprising puzzle game, with a high standard of quality and a humorous undertone.  Any fans of the puzzler-adventure genre should easily find this game enjoyable. Once you start playing you will likely find yourself engrossed by the experience.It has a much thicker, richer story aspect than many other puzzler-adventure games out there. I was truly entertained by the narrative throughout my entire playthrough. The interesting plot goes a long way to elevate this game above the standard. Furthermore, I thought the graphics were nice and the voice acting was solid, which reinforces the high quality of the writing. The end result is a very enjoyable game with an excellent presentation.This inherent quality in the writing, atmosphere, and overall presentation results in a game which feels much more true to the Sherlock Holmes brand than the other couple of games I have played that were franchised the intellectual property.  The others feel like standard adventure games with the words "Sherlock Holmes" on the title. This game, to me, really felt like what I believe a Sherlock Holmes game should feel like. The puzzles were very challenging and quite fun; though to be honest I lost patience and had to seek assistance once or twice because of how tricky some of them were. Some of the puzzles are doubly complicated because the objective of the puzzle isn’t always made clear. So first you have to figure out what you are trying to do, and then you have to actually do it. This does add an extra layer of challenge, but it also can be a bit jarring.And lastly, something I thought was a pretty cool feature is the fact that you can choose to move around in 1st or 3rd person, or play in classic point-and-click adventure style. Having this freedom sounds trivial, but it is really nice to be able to tailor the style on a whim as you play through the campaign.In summary, The Testament of Sherlock Holmes is a pretty sweet ride. It should appeal to both fans of the game genre and fans of the Sherlock Holmes IP. Give it some consideration if it sounds up your alley.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

Short reviewGraphics & sound are good, especially for an adventure game where you usually don't expect much. "Hunt the pixel" is mostly avoided, though you may have to seek around a bit sometimes. There's brilliant moments where you actually feel like Sherlock Holmes when you're deducting the true circumstances of a crime, but those are outnumbered by dodgy moments where you're confronted with unconnected puzzles that really have no reason to be there. Fortunately all such puzzles are skippable, so you won't get frustrated. The story is interesting enough to motivate and feels like classic Holmes, with a twist at the end that may not be everyone's cup of tea but is certainly original.Snap this up when it's on sale, especially if you're a Holmes fan. It feels slightly overpriced at full ($20 at the time of writing).Long reviewThe Testament of Sherlock Holmes is the latest installment (as of writing) in a series that I haven't played. No knowledge of events in the previous games is required, fortunately; there's some allusions but you don't need to know anything about them to play this one. Your very first investigation serves as a tutorial on the controls, and you can simply go from there. This game does not rely on you carefully scanning every inch of the screen with your mouse until you've found the hotspot; you don't have to do more than get close enough and you will get clear indications of what can be investigated. At the same time, this is not so obvious that it takes all the fun out of exploring, and sometimes you do have to backtrack carefully to see what you've missed.For an adventure game in particular, the graphics are good. You won't fall out of your chair in amazement, but character models and environments are all well done and fit the atmosphere of the story. The soundtrack does its job, in that you hardly notice it's there, except for one notably bad case of it playing with an intensity that the situation doesn't warrant -- things only start to happen in that location later, yet the soundtrack is ominous and frantic right from the start. The voice acting for both Holmes and Watson is excellent and the characters come across just right. The other characters are mostly believable, with two notable exceptions: one character who is required to pass for another with a British accent has a painfully obvious faux German accent that shouldn't have fooled anyone, and the actor voicing the main villain sounds like he's taking his cues from cartoons, with the only thing missing being an evil laugh. Both of these break immersion quite badly and mess up what is otherwise fine voice acting.Enough about the window dressing, let's get to the gameplay. Here we get to both the game's best and worst parts. As in all adventure games, you walk around, gathering information and objects, and occasionally apply one object to another. Especially commendable in this regard is that when you do have to combine objects, this makes sense and is easy to do (like combining pieces of rope to make a longer piece of rope) -- sounds obvious, but there are many adventure games where you have to combine unlikely objects in bizarre ways to solve puzzles in the most roundabout way possible. You won't find such puzzles here -- whenever you need to overcome obstacles by combining objects it feels perfectly natural.Unfortunately, what you will find are puzzles that are generic brain teasers (like matching colored balls in some interesting sense or rotating tiles) that have no believable connection to the story and are just there to make you stop and solve them. To the game's great credit, all of these puzzles are skippable after some time has passed, because it would feel really frustrating to *have* to solve them if you didn't want to, or couldn't. Some can be solved by trial and error, some are impossible to do that way, but almost all of them feel like they don't belong in the game and they don't fit in with the narrative. Apparently everybody in Victorian England used intricate locks that can nevertheless be opened without outside help to safeguard their valuables, instead of, you know, keys. The lowest point for me was a series of puzzles in an elementary school that really break immersion by their sheer contrivedness and lack of justification for solving them at all (rather than simply forcing the issue). Elementary, dear player? Hardly.If those were the only puzzles, I couldn't really recommend this game, but it redeems itself with the deduction puzzles. The game's best moments come when you actually get to feel like you're solving crime like the great detective himself, carefully observing for clues and piecing them together in a logical whole using "deduction boards", where you choose from several logical (and less logical) alternatives until both the clues and your deductions line up. Solving these puzzles with a minimum of guessing rewards you with the feeling that you're Holmes himself, coming to seemingly impossible conclusions by eliminating the actually impossible. Even the "chemical analysis" puzzles, which are not really about deduction but about memorizing colored blobs, tie in with the overall atmosphere of crime-solving. The game could have elevated itself considerably if it had more of this and less of the arbitrary puzzles -- in fact, if they ever make another installment, I'd strongly recommend that they only do these deduction puzzles and no more of the mechanical ones. As it is, there are only three or four in the game, with the regular puzzles padding out most of the playtime.The story is the other selling point of the game. The flavor is excellent, and when it works, it's worthy of anything Sir Arthur Conan Doyle has written, with both the mundane and slightly fantastical/unbelievable elements mixed together in a familiar way. The characterization is fine -- Holmes has his dry quips and stoic determination, while Watson is there to reign in his friend's unique brand of callousness where it's warranted, without coming off as a dunce (a common sin in other adaptations). There's nothing original here (except for the end, which we'll get to in a bit) and you've seen most of these elements before in other Holmes stories, but it's all well put together, with the exposition scene where Holmes recaps what's really happened for Watson before the final showdown being especially memorable. It doesn't quite exceed its source material, but it's a valiant effort nonetheless.There's a twist at the end that might leave opinions divided on whether it's of benefit to the story (or whether it should be there at all), but I liked it. After all, this is only one of many stories told of Holmes, and if you don't like what this one's selling, you can always ignore it, but I thought it was a charming idea that I hadn't seen before. Not everything is wrapped up in a neat little bow and there are one or two spots that I'd consider plot holes, but I found myself intrigued and entertained. Overall the level is more "penny dreadful" than Shakespeare, but then, that fits the Victorian era nicely.Bottom line: this is a strong recommendation if you're a fan of Sherlock Holmes as he appears in the Doyle stories. If you're just an adventure game aficionado in general, be warned that this contains some pure puzzles which have little or nothing to do with adventuring, and the remainder is probably not going to challenge you a lot. In either case, at the $20 that is its current asking price it's probably slightly disappointing, but this would be a good one to pick up on a sale.

												This game was quite disappointing. Despite being a detective game, there is very little actual investigations - the game turns into a simple point and click adventure game pretty quickly. As a mystery game, this fails spectacularly... which is surprising considering that this game is quite well made - with the exception of some of the worst animations I've seen in a long time.

												There are perhaps more flaws to this game than it can get away with. However, the areas in which it excels are the most important aspects of a puzzle game such as this, so I'm inclined to give this a thumbs up overall. Bear in mind though, that this game is probably not everyone's cup of tea, depending on how sensitive you are to annoying details and minor flaws.Pros:- The plot is surprising and genuinely intriguing, and keeps you wanting to find out where your next clue leads you.- The puzzles are sufficiently varied and well-made, and not too easy to solve.- The atmosphere fits the game and the story perfectly, including some very good voice-work.Cons:- While the plot is great, it also contains quite a few loose ends and logical shortcomings. Some of the deductions of Mr. Holmes are so far-fetched you've got to wonder if he's high.- Some of the puzzles are overly difficult, and most of them has only rudimentary instructions which are of very little help as to what you're actually supposed to do.- The gameplay is as linear as it gets, and consequently the game has absolutely zero replay-value.- Animations and lip-sync are far below par. There is also weirdly little visual difference between gameplay and cinematics, which makes you wonder why they bothered.- Considering the low-level graphics and effects, the game still manages to take up nearly 10 GB of space.- Running is only marginally faster than walking, which makes some sections fairly tedious.5/10

												This would be a great Sherlock Holmes game if it actually tried to be a Sherlock Holmes game.What I mean is, it starts off really well, and has two investigations that are very interesting, and very much in the vein of what I expect a Sherlock Holmes game to be. You explore a crime scene, noticing very little details about it, and piece them together in a 'deduction board,' an invention of a game which serves to gamify Holmes' famous deductive reasoning. It does a pretty good job of it, too! I also really liked the ONE scene where you analyze evidence you gathered in the crime scene, as there were quite a few clever minigames that I had fun going through.The problem being, basically the entire game after that, save for two further, and much smaller, investigations, is literally just a mediocre puzzle adventure game, with a bunch of stupid 'find item -> use item' puzzles, and with far more puzzle boxes than I think should have existed in the late 19th Century? Normally, I wouldn't mind this...but I don't play a game in the Sherlock Holmes universe to go through puzzles that could be in ANY game. I play a Sherlock Holmes game so I can BE Sherlock Holmes, exploring crime scenes and solving them in a way only he could. And you don't even have the excuse there's so little you can do with that, because just look at all the cases in the public domain stories. There's SO many ways to adapt and expand them without ever resorting to stupid puzzle♥♥♥♥♥♥that even Sierra was doing back in the 80s.That being said, I do like the voice work of Holmes and Watson, especially Holmes. And the environments are pretty well done, especially for a lower-budget game like this. I wish the engine was a little better, as controlling Holmes and Watson felt like trying to drive a drunken tank at times, but it didn't hamper my experience of the game too much. Though, there WAS a bit too much backtracking, and, yeah, the scene with the dog was completely pointless.As for the story...it started out pretty well, and then went to♥♥♥♥♥♥at the end. Minor spoilers from here on out.So Moriarty's in the game, because apparently you just have to use Moriarty as much as you can, despite there being perfectly fine villains in the mythos. I understand this is part of a series, and he would be suited for 'Holmes' darkest case yet,' but he basically just shows up at the end with little fanfare, and he's just this utterly-generic 'evil for the sake of evil' villain, not at all the criminal mastermind and equal to Holmes he should be. What buildup there is was fine, but his appearance was completely underwhelming.Not to mention, the final twist at the very end, once Moriarty's dealt with. I actually would have REALLY liked that, and thought it would be a great way to take Holmes as a character...except it's literally JUST introduced seconds before the credits roll. We're given no development, no buildup, it's just a way to cheaply garner audience sympathy right at the very end. It almost comes across as a deus-ex-machina, if it had ANY bearing on the plot. Moriarty doesn't even mention it until he's [SPOILERS] and uses it as his motivation in basically two words.I would have loved it if we kept meeting Moriarty as the game went on, and he kept hinting about it, and he kept saying he had a reason for his crimes this time around, and it kept us in the dark and serves as a primary motivation to his character, rather than he's just doing it because he's evil.This game could have used much better writing in general. For being called one of the best Sherlock Holmes games up to now, it's surprisingly amateurish. I just can't give it a recommendation, even though it has just enough of the Holmesian spirit to get me wanting more. If you want to buy it, buy it in a sale when it's 75% off, because I don't think it's worth much more than $5-10.I really hope the next game, Crime and Punishment, will actually satisfy me. I DO have The Awakening, so maybe that will, too.

												Being a fan of the TV show 'Sherlock', I had to play this game. This is my first Sherlock Holmes game and I was pleasantly surprised. The Testament of Sherlock Holmes is a point-and-click adventure game where you play as Sherlock (and Watson) trying to resolve the murder of a Reverend in his own church. I won't say more about the story since the main reason of playing this game is to discover that.The gameplay is faily simple. Where you can interact, there is either a magnifying glass to look at some items or a hand to show that you can take the item or that you can interact with it. That's it. Most of the time, you'll have to look through everything to be sure that you didn't miss any important clue. The rooms are small enough so it's really easy to find everything.Also, as a detective, there is a deduction board. You'll have to discover every clues to see statements about them. With these facts, it's up to you to choose between 3 answers which one is the right one about what happened in this case. There are multiple questions to be answered and you won't know if you're right until you have all the right answers. It can be hard but if you pay attention to the story, it will be fairly easy. There is also a lot of puzzles in this game. Some are logic and really easy once you understand how they work but some of the puzzles that does NOT involve any deduction/logic can be really hard and frustrating for some people. There is a skip buttons after some minutes so don't worry !One of the problem in this game is that it's too linear for a detective game. There is no real choice to be made and even if you choose to go to a location instead of another, you'll end up going to both places without any change.The story is really interesting and there are a lot of twists (I found it similar to the TV show and it's a good thing). The problem (because it's a videogame !) is that Sherock is not as funny as Cumberbatch's Sherlock (but it's understandable since there is no actor involved). In conclusion, if you like point-and-click games, you'll like this one. It will definitely entertain you for hours ! (I finished the game in about 7-8 hours)

The Testament Of Sherlock Holmes			* 8/10This is one of the latest chapters of Frogware's Sherlock Franchise and if I have to describe it briefly with a word or a concept that would be "Experience". Experience doesn't mean perfection but seeing how they started (the mistery of the mummy) and all the other titles they went through you can see how all the titles evolved, improved and changed chapter by chapter with good news and new mistakes. Even though The testament of Sherlock Holmes isn't perfect I really consider it a great improvement, a big leap into a new generation of the Sherlock Franchise.The Testament of Sherlock Holmes is a point and click adventure with third person view. Gameplay uses pretty much the usual mechanics, you can observe, use or pickup items according to the icon it displays when you get on it with your cursor, and besides the usual combination of items there are riddles and puzzles and some of the are tough and random. when you're done with the clues of the current section you will be prompted to complete a deduction scheme, where you will link concepts and clues together with deductions (which YOU must choose between a choice of three possibilities). From this point of view this chapter doesn't represent anything particularily new, but it's mostly a very refined and polished verion of what has been already done in the previous chapter, Sherlock Vs The Ripper. The real innovation and leap forward to a new level is represented by three factors, Story, graphics and soundtrack.The story begins with a small section used to explain the gameplay in which Sherlock will quickly solve a case of a stolen necklace. Later they will learn from newspapers that Sherlock is being accused of returning a false necklace. And from here the story is a succession of facts and situations that will lead to a dangerous degeneration of his good name. And I won't say no more because this is a great story with plot twists which represent its best parts.Graphics is a great improvement considering the previous chapters and their remasters. It doesn't surprise much the fact that they employed the Unreal Engine 3 and even though you can't say the result is a true miracle of beauty you can undoubtely see that the results are great and various locations filled with many contour details and even though some animations can be a bit rigid, some situations can be a little buggy and few areas here and there are simply clipped to prevent exploring useless zones, now you see a new type of approach for the narration as it has been paid more attention to camera settings with focus and effects, new expressive animations (even though they're the same ones often repeating they're still new).This chapter's soundtrack is completely new and it's a magnificent set of orchestral pieces that will pleasently accompany you during all your investigations and will also set a more pressing atmosphere when there will be some tense situations. Unfortunately I believe there are few tracks as I heard the same tracks in more situations and sections. I still love them, but I believe a few tracks more could have avoided this feeling.A small note to praise some gameplay sections, especially the ones with Toby (Sherlock's Hound... Yes, you control him... XD) and the ones with Watson, because you will usually need his small help a few times, but there will be entire sections with Watson alone and I've been waiting for this as Watson is not just a mere doctor incapable of any deduction but he really has some skills and in this chapter he will prove that more than once and I'm very glad about this. And one last praise for the credits... Yes the credits. It doesn't make any sense, I know, but I just love that art because the it reminds me a lot about Casinò Royale openings...+++PROs+++ STORY. Clearly the best point of this chapter is the story, very intense, degenerating and involving, but I can't say much because it deserves not to be spoilt. GRAPHICS & ART. A very big leap to the next level thanks to a very good use of the Unreal Engine 3, lots of neat details in various and coloured ambiences, great cutscenes with camera settings and focus effects, new good expressive animations. SOUNDTRACK. A sweet and great score with beautiful orchestral tracks that will pleasently accompany the gameplay with proper tones in the different situations. GAMEPLAY. A very well refined gameplay, based on the previous titles but more polished and accurate. Great and interesting puzzles and riddles and original nice sections with Toby and Watson.---CONs--- MUSIC & ANIMATIONS VARIETY. I personally believe that a few animations and music tracks could have improved the experience because during the game you will notice that songs tend to repeat in various secions and characters move in the same way during speeches. RESTART THE GAME TO APPLY THE SETTINGS. And still nowadays I am forced to restart the game to apply the video settings. Kind of unexpected...

Good immersion, I'd say.Fans of the books will appreciate some easter egg references to past adventures, plus the fun of taking Toby for a spin once again (with some added skills he didn't have in the book; I think he was smarter than Watson in this one...)The puzzles had that perfect balance of challenging without making me tear clumps of my hair out.  The very few times I consulted a walkthrough was in situations where I knew I'd forgotten to pick something up earlier and didn't want to have backtrack too far for it.  It was unnecessary for the puzzles themselves, which took me a lot of thinking but no random rage-quits over it. :DI will mention there is some "digital" gore due to a couple of rather grisly murder scenes, in case that matters to you.  I cringed a little bit at doing a post-mortem exam, but the sequence was mercifully short.  I'm naturally squeamish and it really wasn't enough to bother me much.  Just wanting to throw that out there for anyone who wants to know!Overall, an excellent experience and one that was so entertaining I'll probably go back and play it again at a later date, which isn't a treatment I give to too many games. All in all, however, it's likely the best game in the series so far, so if you liked the others, you'll like this one, too. 												Real fans of classic point and click adventure games will be ashamed to have played this. The core mechanics of finding and analyzing clues are grossly linear. And as far as I can tell, much of the story is filled out by Holmes' sporadic arbitrary narratives, which relate only vaguely to the clues you've gathered. It makes you feel like you just have to go pick up a prescribed number of rocks before Holmes divulges impossibly-omniscient information on the case. While this may or may not be in the style of traditional Sherlock Holmes, it is not in any way satisfying as a plot progression mechanic in a game.Also the few puzzle-based asides are entirely self-contained and have little or nothing to do with the story or any details you may have observed. On top of that the movement, much like the GUI, is clunky and annoying, in all 3 of the view modes, and makes you feel like you have nubs for hands.The "deduction board" is a fairly smart mechanic, but is ruined by the fact that it's closely tied to whether or not you simply clicked on certain pre-determined clue hotspots. It would be infinitely more challenging if you were allowed to simply examine the various scenes and fill out the deduction board yourself, instead of it breaking everything down to meaningless and often absurd multiple choice statements.TL:DR; Far too linear and simplistic for a veteran adventure gamer, but much too tedious and clunky for casual gaming.

												An atmospheric Sherlock Holmes game with a good story. The 3D characters look nice but are somewhat robotic, including the protagonists. The voice acting is generally good, although Holmes and Watson's exchanges can be weird; Watson especially brings to mind an alien trying to figure out the correct reply, at times.The puzzles are hit and miss, but all the coffee break style minigames can be skipped if wanted. The larger problem is that there's a fair amount of item hunting, in areas where it's unclear what you're even trying to achieve. There's a deduction board which you must fill with clues and then use the power of deduction to make the right conclusions. This was one of the best parts of the previous Frogwares titles, and it's nice to see it's still present.From a technical standpoint the game is fairly solid. The graphics and sound are both very good and the game runs well. The control scheme is simple and doesn't get in the way. I do wish Frogwares learned to program proper mouse controls, though - the 1st person mouse control is even worse than in their previous 3D Sherlock titles. There's an annoying dead zone in the vertical axis in addition to the general floatiness, which is not caused by vertical sync or low frame rate. At least the vertical axis can be reversed.The Testament should also get a prize for the weirdest intro video in a long time, in which a trio of really weird looking children find a book in an attic. It's a complete mess. One of the kids looks like a ventriloquist's doll and they all behave like they're from a fever dream.Still, it's a very good game and definitely worth playing.

												This game is a boon for everyone who likes to be mentally challenged by puzzles. The puzzles in this game has cost me quite some time to solve and it was pleasing to find a logical answer everytime.However, keep in mind I'm new to this kind of games, there are some downsides. I'm a sucker for a good story and having read the collection of Sherlock Holmes books of Doyle himself, I found the story overdone. Sherlock Holmes is ofcourse known for revealing his cards at the end, so the plottwists were something which was unsuprising and I didn't mind it. The kids throughout the story though was a waste of time in my opinion. They were graphically of lower quality, got me out of the story everytime and didn't fit in Sherlock's character.  Second, some clues and items were hard to find. The game has a help mechanism, but when used often, you get a badge. So that felt like a punishment. Gamers will have to ignore  that badge and keep using Sherlock's senses anyway. There is a precise order of doing certain things, which can't be done otherwise. There is a puzzle with Greek letters, which can be found in books, on internet or the player can know them already by heart, however, Sherlock still needs to find a list with the letters.Lastly, the way Sherlock and Watson are moved around. There are three ways: first person, third person and a room/area overview. None of those really felt natural and easy. There is one absolute reason to buy (or get it with Crimes and Punishments, like I did): the puzzles. As said before, they are challenging, but all beatable. After five minutes (+/-) you get the option to let Sherlock solve it, so you can't get stuck. I recommend to try and solve them all, since that's the thrill!

												Intriguing game, but not without flaws.I just love investigation games where you have to find clues and then deduce to figure out what really happened, and you definitely expect that from a Sherlock Holmes game. In that department it doesn't fail to deliver, except that I wish there was more of it. The story of the game is fairly interesting too, quite dark and a bit out there. It is good to see that a developer is trying something new and original, but this was not a success in my eyes.What really stands out in this game, in my opinion, is the voice acting. I found the deduction boards to be creative and fun and the puzzle boxes to be less so. Either way I enjoyed the game as a whole and would easily recommend it to anyone enjoying these types of games.I rate the game 7/10Happy Gaming!

Posted: June 27, 2014
												The Testament Of Shrlock Homes is a hybrid point and click 3d exploration game.  Theres a lot of work that has gone into this, with numerous backgrounds and environments, costumes, 3d level constructions, some nice facial animations (that are occasionally totally out of sync with the speech), some questionable voice acting and some mind testing puzzles.From a story perspective, this game is rather faithful to the Sherlock Holmes books, and theres been some obvious research done into the character, his relationships and the world he inhabits.  Theres also some obvious  problems with the game that mar an otherwise enjoyable 3D explorer. The story is fairly good.  It does take some liberties with the historic Holmes and brings back the baddest bad guy ever, but overall, it stays faithful to the period.  That said, there are some points when it breaks down and you have to take a leap of faith with the character to continue playing.  I didnt like that sometimes, plot devices were revealed bythe narration and cut scenes before they had happened in the game, but its not a terribly unforgivable problem.The puzzle solving is where this game excels.  some of the quests require lateral thinking and some interesting approaches to solve.  some however require you to go through a monotonous sqeuence of events.  They are less enjoyable, but thankfully are few and far between.Ive seen elsewhere comments about "ugliest children ever!" and that aspect of the game could have been much better.  Some of the events you have to follow make no sense at all.  theres a massive twist in the game that you expect from Sherlock Holmes, but it makes no attempt to explain why, how or what its playing at.The multi character system is a great idea, allowing you to be in two places at once, and its a good way to link up character arcs in game, but sometimes its overused.The entire last act of the game is, frankly, boring.  the first 2 thirds of the game work rather well and were far more enjoyable.  Some puzzles require you to find a specirfic item, and those are REALLY annyoing particularly because the location of some of the items make no sense.  in the same breath however, some of the interactions with third person characters  is innovative, although some of them are so diaposable, you forget about them.  I consider that a problem of the character developlment, and some interesting characters never re-occur, leaving you let down a their underuse.All in all, this is a solid adventure, but it wont win any awards, which is unfortunate.  Id like to see one of these tackled with a proper development budget, better voice acting and some streamlined quests, but if youre a fan of the genre or sherlock holmes, you'll probably find something in this game to satisfy you.  give it a go!  its mega cheap in the Steam Sale!

												A wonder and frustrating puzzle - The Testament of Sherlock Holmes provides hours of gameplay that ease you into the role of consulting detective. Set as a rememberance by three small children, you go about London, solving crimes that, at first, seem non-related. With point and click clues, deduction boards and the creating of new items from what you've found, there's always something to discover! That is, if you don't quit after getting caught in the cutscenes. Often long and unneeded, they cut into an otherwise seemless gameplay. Perhaps replace them with requiring more action from the player would work. Need a place to hide? Some are easier than others but if you're not Holmes yourself, perhaps have a hint page pulled up online. (That way, you still get the satisfaction of 'having done it mostly myself'.) Why is Watson fooled by the warden's sudden RIDICULOUS FORCED GERMAN ACCENT? Since when did Moriarty become Kefka from Final Fantasy 6?  There are times when the story in this game felt sillier than the Cthulhu game, but at least the Cthulhu game knew it was camp! 												Other than a short go at Sherlock Holmes vs. Jack The Ripper (42 minutes according to Steam), this is my first experience with the new series of Sherlock Holmes games, and - my memory might elude me - even "new school" point and click adventures in general. Let me add that the genre of point and click adventure / puzzle games is one I have built a love-hate relationship with over the years. For every game with a gripping storyline, great characters, and mostly logical and fun puzzles, there seem to be three (possibly up to n-1) that send you on a pixel-for-pixel hunt for items and constantly obstruct your progress in the most obscure way possible.That being said, I have used a guide for parts of this game. Maybe I could have done it without, but sometimes, after searching the same 3 places over and over again for that one item or observation that allows you to progress, you're faced with the choice of using a guide or uninstalling the game, and I kinda wanted to finish it after all.The game looks decent, but it doesn't feel great. You have the choice between first person, 3rd person, and point-and-click mode, all of which feel a bit clunky at times. The voice acting didn't strike me neither as great, nor terrible - it works. People seem to think that this game is very gritty, mature and dark (compared to what exactly?). There's the occasional graphic scene, but all in all it's pretty much exactly what you'd expect from a Sherlock Holmes game. At least it's pretty much what I had expected, I guess. The story didn't have me jump up from my chair in regular intervals (or at all for that matter), but it's enough to keep you going.As suggested earlier, The Testament of Sherlock Holmes isn't free of typical adventure game moments. Now, I'm certainly not a genius, but I'm not a complete knucklehead, either. At least not all the time. Sometimes I just got stuck. I don't remember how often exactly, but it will probably happen to you. Or maybe it won't and I'm just really bad at this. Anyway, a hint system other than the "6th Sense" - that didn't really do anything useful for me when I used it - would've helped here.So, would I recommend buying this game?The answer is a clear "it depends". Do you enjoy this sort of game and can you live with the inherent quirks and issues of the genre? Do you have a large sum of money at your disposal or can you get the game on sale for no more than 5-8 bucks (or both)? If you can answer both questions with yes, then sure, go for it. There are worse ways of spending a couple of hours (there are also better ways, but aren't there always?).

Any fans of the puzzler-adventure genre should easily find this game enjoyable. The others feel like standard adventure games with the words "Sherlock Holmes" on the title. This game, to me, really felt like what I believe a Sherlock Holmes game should feel likeThe puzzles were very challenging and quite fun; though to be honest I lost patience and had to seek assistance once or twice because of how tricky some of them were. content:

												*HEAVY SPOILERS HEREIN, CAVEAT LECTOR*The more I play these Sherlock Holmes games released by FrogWares, the more I see a decline in their execution. Elsewhere I have read a review that criticized the franchise for its emphasis on the macabre, but some of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's stories did the same, although his main appeal was in how they captured the zeitgeist of the Victorian age, in the clash of science and superstition ("The Hound of the Baskervilles" is probably the more famous case), the importance of propriety ("The Adventure of the Solitary Cyclist"), the attraction for the exotic and the imperial ("The Sign of the Four", "The Adventure of the Speckled Band"). These are not primarily famous for their plot ingenuity -- in this respect, Conan Doyle's masterpiece is probably "Silver Blaze", which is thoroughly rational but mundane -- but for having cemented the view we have of the mores of late Victorian England. The people at Frogwares seem to be aware of that, but that does not mean they are respectful of the franchise. The Holmesian stuff is just atmospheric detail on a typical puzzle game, and I think the most telling indication of it is the dichotomy (see also The Awakened, Nemesis and Jack the Ripper) between the log-in/option screen and the puzzles, and the game world itself. While they seem to pay a great deal of attention to the game world (even though they get sloppy at times by reusing the same period illustrations over and over again, some of it mirrored). they seem to pick the default sans serif font for menu options without having second thoughts about it. Which not only makes the game look cheaper than it is (remember how The Awakened did not even have the game's name on the main menu?), but betrays that it is, beneath the Sherlockian veneer, a puzzle game. Which means that anything goes.In this game, for example, we get bombs made with radios, never mind that this is set in Old Vicky's England, where the closest equivalent one had to radio networks was broadcast by telephone, and where Signor Marconi was still experimenting with wireless telegraphy. Yet this game would have us believe that not only could radio parts be available to your average Russian (what else?) anarchists, but that the bombs in question could be remotely activated by a gigantic antenna. And there is the problem of the plot, if indeed there is one. A bishop asks SH to come and see him. Bishop is killed after hours of torture for a reason unknown. SH learns of a visit by bishop's nephew the previous day, who vanished. SH traces one of the assassins to Whitechapel (thereby enabling the reuse of valuable artwork from Jack the Ripper), but finds that the man has been killed by his accomplices, who are arrested in an opium den. SH finds that a rare poison has been used, *therefore* a certain famous poisoner has to be involved (because there can only be one famous poisoner at a time), even though said poisoner was currently detained at Her Majesty's pleasure, which means of course that SH has to facilitate his escape. Meanwhile a yellow reporter was writing derogatory articles about SH for which he benefited from inside information, which SH traces to a judge (out of the three sitting on the bench throughout the British Isles, if the puzzle is to be believed). SH burglarizes said judge's house, finds out the trove of information the judge keeps about him. Just after Holmes and Watson leave, the judge gets home just in time for the place to blow up.SH, believing he is about to be blamed for the explosion, goes into hiding. Watson finds him at one of his other addresses. SH and Watson go to an old mill where Russian anarchists hang out. Scotland Yard soon intervenes. SH shoots the inspector. When later cornered at 221B, SH kills himself in front of Watson.  Now, I don't know exactly how someone can fake shooting himself in the head (with all the gore that follows) within two metres of a man whose letters M.D. after his name are supposed to stand for something other than Mostly Decorative, but Watson believes it, goes strolling down sewers because that's where you're supposed to go for contemplation, I suppose, and discovers not only that SH is still alive, but that Moriarty is behind all the events in question, which involve feeding poisoned soup to beggars so that they will go crazy and foment a rebellion to install a relative of dear old Vicky on the throne, with the help of the master poisoner and Russian anarchists who have planted bombs around London. It's like if you took all the organizations mentioned in JFK conspiracy theories and made them work together.This game is a magnificent exercise in "when things can't be explained, don't try, and hope nobody notices". What information exactly did the bishop have? We don't know. Why was his nephew hiding out in a steel foundry to avoid discovery, and by whom? Don't know. How could the poisoner have contributed to the plan from his cell when he was not even provided with writing materials? Don't know. The game ushers us from one location to another without ever bothering to tie any of the loose ends, except for the occasional passing mention in dialogue.Overall, there has always been something disappointing about Frogwares' Holmes franchise. As an atmospheric exercise, "Sherlock Holmes versus Jack the Ripper" was better, but I find it questionable to use historical murders as the background for a video game. (That game did not even bother to rely on one of the numerous existing theories about that particular series of crimes, like the one, deep into conspiracy territory, that had to do with the Duke of Clarence's dalliance with harlots, which at least would have justified why Holmes solved the crime but that nobody ever heard a thing about it, and naturally it's been done before - see the film "Murder by Decree".) As a crime-solving game, it never gets intricate enough; it never attempts to be more than just another puzzle game. (They sure had fancy safes in the Victorian era.) Part of my disappointment with this game is really with the franchise's stubborn refusal to be more than it is, but here it fails as a game even if I just based my assessment on the story alone.

												I should start saying that this one belongs to the adventure category, and it's of the same spirit as the old-school, 2D poin-n-click games. It seems necessary to point that out, because, apparently, some reviewers let the 3D graphics fool them, and forgot about this fact. As a matter of fact, no other adventure could really beat this one in graphics or atmosphere, but it's still an adventure game; not an action game, not a RPG. And it's great at that. Anyone who feels the need of a change in pace, and want to slow down a little bit, and imerse themselves in a fantastic world of decadence, misteries and violent, apparently unsolvable crimes, can always count with the cold-blooded, logically-minded Mr. Holmes, and the loyal and righteous Dr. Watson as their guides. The characters are inarguably great on this one. Sherlock Holmes is clearly at his best, but Dr. Watson really awes the player for his distinction: a completely independent and complex character on his own. Their voices match perfectly and are totally convincing. Actually, the whole soundtrack is perfectly adequate to the game as a whole. Really good adventure, indeed. But, to be honest, there are some drawbacks also. The player will be every now and then distracted by the likes of bad lip sincronization, the somewhat awkward character movimentation, clunky gameplay, lots of invisible walls, and lack of animations when using objects. SummaryA decent enough adventure game and a treat for fans of Sherlock Holmes.ReviewI won't say this is the best adventure game I've ever played, but I enjoyed it for what it was worth.  The fact that I'm a big fan of Sherlock Holmes did help me look past some of the game's rougher spots, but I'm not sure someone else would be so forgiving.  The overall narrative, suffice it to say, is no match for the Sir Arthur Conan Doyle originals, but it's enough to hold the game together, which is really the most you can expect from a video game story.I called this an adventure game, but I think "puzzle game" might be a more fitting description.  Who knew the denizens of Victorian London were so fond of locking their secrets behind intricate logic puzzles?  You will encounter around two-dozen puzzles throughout the course of completing the game, and while I didn't find the puzzles particularly difficult once I understood them, the rules and operations of the puzzles were sometimes vague, so it wasn't always obvious to me what I was supposed to do, or if it was obvious, it wasn't obvious exactly how I was supposed to go about doing it.  I suppose that's part of the gameplay experience, figuring out exactly what the puzzle is and how to solve it, but there were times I honestly wasn't sure if this was intentional or simply poor game design.  No matter, walk throughs are easy enough to find on the internet these days if you need a prod in the right direction; alternatively, the game does present the option to simply skip a puzzle if you're well and truly stumped, but what self-respecting gamer would choose that route?There are also the more traditional adventure game puzzles that have you exploring your environment for clues, picking up everything you possibly can, and occasionally combining various objects in your inventory so you can proceed.  Thankfully, the game has a "Sixth Sense" feature where you press the spacebar to momentarily have points of interest highlighted for you which eliminates the frustrating pixel hunt.The presentation is a somewhat mixed bag.  The environments and character models are generally oustanding with great attention to detail and lots of atmospheric touches that really make Victorian London come to life.  The overall character animations are good for the most part, but the lipsynching is atrocious with the characters frequently flapping their lips for a few seconds after delivering their lines, which I found distracting, and the voice acting is average at best.  I never really took to Watson's melodramatic delivery where every line is spoken with an awkward urgency, and Holmes speaks in a drone, sounding almost bored at times, as if the whole business of crime solving no longer interested him.  Curiously, the bit players you encounter throughout the game are often better acted and sound more convincing then the stars of the show.The game controls well enough with a mouse and keyboard, although the mouse movements felt somewhat sluggish even with the sensitivity turned up to maximum in the settings. I played mostly from the third-person perspective which gives you a good view of your surroundings, and while a traditional adventure game perspective is offered, I found the controls too awkward (although people with a gamepad seem to have good success playing from this perspective).  I'd like to pass on a couple of tips on controlling the game since I'm not sure if it's mentioned in the manual: 1) you can use the mouse wheel to quickly scroll through individual items in your inventory; this is a lot faster and more convenient than opening your inventory screen, although you still have to open it if you want to combine one object with another; 2) if you have a bunch of hotspots clustered together, you can click the left-mouse button to highlight one and then use the WASD keys to cycle through them until you've highlighted the one you want; click the left-mouse button a second time to activate it; otherwise it's just way too fiddly to try and maneuver your character into the right position.I realize this review might seem overly critical, but none of the criticisms I've noted are fatal, and I did spend an enjoyable 14-hours completing this game.  With the noted exceptions, the puzzles are clever and fun to solve, and I have to say again that I found the art design to be terrific making each area a joy to explore, particularly when I came across obscure references to the original Conan Doyle stories.  If you're a fan of adventrue games, and especially Sherlock Holmes, and you think you could look past the weaknesses I've noted, then I would recommend this game.

Evidently a good game, my dear Watson.The Testament of Sherlock Holmes, a game I'd never heard of before. The fact that is was 75% off and was recommended by some steam users made me buy it. I never would have expected that it would be one of the best games I've played i the past few months.The story is pretty obviuos and sometimes predictable, and the ending was, in my opinion, a bit ridiculous. the graphics are pretty okay, considering this is not a triple A title. The animations are sometimes a bit dodgy and funny looking, and the lack of lip sync is also pretty funny if you start to notice it. But these are not the points that make or break a game for me. No, for me it's all about gameplay, and boy did this game do that right.The searching for clues is sometimes really straight forward, but many times you will be really surprised by where you'll have to look or what you'll have to do to find that one little clue or object you desperately need. And when you do find it, you WILL feel satisfied. The only little downside to this is a little lack of freedom. For example when you already know what needs do be done next, the game forces you to find that one last clue before you can go any further in the story, even of you already know the solution.The puzzles are awesome and sometimes you really have to think about them (hardest one took me half an hour of scribbling possible solutions on pieces of paper at my desk).The dialogue is brilliant, and despite the above named lack of lip sync, the facial expressions are rather good. You can really tell how someone feels by looking at them. The witty remarks of Sherlock Holmes are really entertaining and overall the crime solving duo has been really well represented in the game.Conclusion: I can't wait untill the next game from this company and give it a solid 8.5/10

Some of them seemed pointless, like "Why did you take me to this 2D screen just for me to click and drag 1 item?" Some of them were just so so. But lastly, some of the puzzles were really cool. I liked the 2D colored marble moving puzzle a lot. The puzzle above the haunted house maze is one of the coolest 3D puzzles I've seen in a game like this.Overall I would have recommended this game if it wasn't for one thing: crashes to desktop during saving on the final level. During the game I think I crashed once during saving until I got to the last level. I think there is something about the graphics on this level that causes you to crash to desktop 50% - 75% of the time during saving. I looked this up on steam and other people have had the problem too. One thing that helped them and seemed to help me was playing in windowed mode. Another thing that seemed to help was saving while staring at the ground or a wall instead of looking out towards any scenery. I ended up doing most of the puzzles on the last level 2 to 5 times. I have to admit I got mad, but I felt so close to the end that I soldiered through it. It ended up taking probably at least an extra 2 hours to keep repeating the last level.

												Everything looks quite nice, especially the setting. For the most part I have no problem with the graphics, a touch old-fashioned though they may be.  The poor lip-syncing and the harrowingly dead eyes of everyone except perhaps Holmes, however, are annoying. Not to mention those pictures of the judges, which were just embarrassing...The plot is interesting and suitably grim, although there were some parts which made little sense. The frame story, I'm sorry to say, I didn't care for at all. The dialogue is interesting, occasionally even quite funny, and there isn't an excess of pointless blather. Holmes' witty retorts deserve a mention of their own, and I quite liked his voice-actor. I also liked the fact that you get to play several characters, not just him. However, there were instances where I wish I had been given freer hands to interrogate people and arrive at conclusions.The puzzles aren't patronisingly easy, nor nerve-wrackingly difficult. Nor are they repetitive. There were a couple which I chose to skip after three or four tries simply because they didn't exactly fall within my field of expertise. Some might find the lack of instructions a nuisance, but I didn't mind.All in all, I quite enjoyed it, even if occasionally I did get frustrated. 7/10+ You actually get to do some deducing.+ The sixth sense is a wonderful aid when you feel like you have reached an impasse.- Oh, Watson, won't you get out of my way!- There are only so many faces in London, apparently. I wish the creators would have been more inventive so that at least all the characters somewhat relevant to the plot would have their own unique faces.- There were one or two factual errors.

I was dubious about how this game would be playable at all, because the charm of Sherlock Holmes is that his mind functions completely differently from a normal human being. Everything is very linear, there's no real gameplay beyond a few really simple logic puzzles and clicking around on things. The voice acting is very, very, VERY wooden. The UI is pretty terrible. The maps are very static.... With rare exception, nothing movies, nobody interacts with the environment, and the vast majority of those exceptions are during cutscenes. I was shocked that such a small game took something like 9gb to install. 												I am a big fan of the Sherlock Holmes games. I love the character, I love the mysteries, I love the atmosphere, and I love the pixel-hunting. There, I said it! Now that I've gotten that back, let me tell you what I think of the Testement of Sherlock Holmes.First, the good things. 1. As usual, the atmosphere is spot on. And I could swear that the dialogue is written by Conan Doyle himself. It genuinely feels like a Sherlock Holmes adventure. 2. The investigation is really well done. Whenever you need to search a body for marks or a room for clues, it feels like L. A. Noire. 3. The tension in the first half of the game is really thrilling. The sense that Sherlock Holmes may be insane, or not who he says he is is gripping and kept me playing to try and decipher why exactly Sherlock Holmes was being so edgy and confrontation. There is no greater conflict in a Sherlock Holmes adventure than questioning the legitimacy of your hero.Now, let's talk about what' bad. 1. Puzzles. Puzzles, Puzzles, Puzzles, Puzzles, Puzzles! Way too many puzzles, and most of them are stupid, complicated, and have no explanation of mechanics, objective, or context. I am grateful that the game includes a "skip puzzle" button, but it's a bad sign when it needs to be included. 2. Adventure-game inventory management. In the early game, the investigation of murders was so strong in gameplay, that it was a shock when I started to have to search for random objects with no idea why I needed them or how they were supposed to be used. Most of the rest of the game is classic combine this with that and use it on that. This wouldn't be a problem, if it was simply transitions between one mystery to another. But instead it makes up the majority of gameplay, and doesn't do it particularly well. 3. The ending is completely non-sequitor and the prologue with awkwardly animated and voice-acted children is really poorly handled, it almost felt like a completely different story spliced into one about Sherlock Holmes struggling with an insidious threat to his integrity. 4. I hesitate to mention this, because I am a strong believer that poor graphics, animation, voice acting, etc. can be compensated for by compelling gamplay. And Bullfrog has come a long way since Sherlock Holmes: the Awakened in terms of animation and cinematics, but it still looks pretty amateur, and it would go a long way for their franchise if they worked on animation and cinematic timing.So ultimately, I recommend this game for its strong beginning and great tension. But regret that it missed its mark in a lot of technical respects.

												Actually very well done, though sometimes a little buggy and jumpy. The puzzles were pretty clever, as to be expected of a Sherlock Holmes game. The story was a bit lackluster and underdramatic, and the voice acting was a little shoddy, with actors putting a little bit too much overemphasis on some of their characters lines. One of the "great reveals" at the end was pretty predictable, at least to anyone has has any two-sense of Sherlock Holmes fiction, and a lot of the story scenes used in the game were mashups of different Holmes stories.  It fits the theme of the older Sherlock Holmes stories however, something people forget about due to the two shows that place Sherlock's tales in a more modern setting. The game contains many references to Sherlock's more famous previous adventures as well, which served as a plus and a great homage to the character's legacy.  The game allowed a great choice of being played in third-person, first-person or even point and click, which is what most games of this genre usually end up being. It was a delight to play in first-person view and search the areas for clues, as if you were the great Holmes himself. Also, playing that random scene as the dog in first person view was a good chuckle.   The game adds the use of a "Deduction Board" where you use clues found in the area to piece together the facts of the case. It was a marvelous idea, definitely one of the better features of the game, though I wish it could have been used more than the three times it is in the game.   Overall I think the game is a worthy buy, especially to fans of the mystery/adventure genre. Pick it up, I had good fun with it.  Additionally, the visuals and music during the ending credits sequence were and absolute marvel to watch, if only they had put something similar in the beginning of the game, allowing it to open with such an impact.

												I am a big fan of the Sherlock Holmes games. I love the character, I love the mysteries, I love the atmosphere, and I love the pixel-hunting. There, I said it! Now that I've gotten that back, let me tell you what I think of the Testement of Sherlock Holmes.First, the good things. 1. As usual, the atmosphere is spot on. And I could swear that the dialogue is written by Conan Doyle himself. It genuinely feels like a Sherlock Holmes adventure. 2. The investigation is really well done. Whenever you need to search a body for marks or a room for clues, it feels like L. A. Noire. 3. The tension in the first half of the game is really thrilling. The sense that Sherlock Holmes may be insane, or not who he says he is is gripping and kept me playing to try and decipher why exactly Sherlock Holmes was being so edgy and confrontation. There is no greater conflict in a Sherlock Holmes adventure than questioning the legitimacy of your hero.Now, let's talk about what' bad. 1. Puzzles. Puzzles, Puzzles, Puzzles, Puzzles, Puzzles! Way too many puzzles, and most of them are stupid, complicated, and have no explanation of mechanics, objective, or context. I am grateful that the game includes a "skip puzzle" button, but it's a bad sign when it needs to be included. 2. Adventure-game inventory management. In the early game, the investigation of murders was so strong in gameplay, that it was a shock when I started to have to search for random objects with no idea why I needed them or how they were supposed to be used. Most of the rest of the game is classic combine this with that and use it on that. This wouldn't be a problem, if it was simply transitions between one mystery to another. But instead it makes up the majority of gameplay, and doesn't do it particularly well. 3. The ending is completely non-sequitor and the prologue with awkwardly animated and voice-acted children is really poorly handled, it almost felt like a completely different story spliced into one about Sherlock Holmes struggling with an insidious threat to his integrity. 4. I hesitate to mention this, because I am a strong believer that poor graphics, animation, voice acting, etc. can be compensated for by compelling gamplay. And Bullfrog has come a long way since Sherlock Holmes: the Awakened in terms of animation and cinematics, but it still looks pretty amateur, and it would go a long way for their franchise if they worked on animation and cinematic timing.So ultimately, I recommend this game for its strong beginning and great tension. But regret that it missed its mark in a lot of technical respects.

												This is one of the best adventures games I've ever played.  The story was deep and immersive with unpredictable twists and turns. When you're controlling Holmes, and Watson isn't off completing his own mission, Watson has this urge to get right up close to Holmes which often impedes Holmes' movement.  After a while you start to anticipate this behaviour and you go round him before he corners you. 												Being an avid fan of Sherlock Holmes games, I have to say this had the most compelling story so far. Although its predecessors were also very intriguing, their plots twists and endings were somewhat obvious, because most gamers were very familiar with stories of Arsene Lupin, Jack the Ripper and Lovecraft. This one kept me interested and guessing throughout the game and I was pleasantly surprised with the ending. Some small details may put you off in the beginning but rest assured that all will be very neatly explained towards the end a la Sherlock Holmes fashion. It is very nicely paced also and character driven instead of the usual murder mystery thriller style, which works very well with the theme and feels fresh.Apart from the story, the gameplay is easy to get used to but you can still see the console port forced in there when you look at the user interfaces.  A point&click camera angle can be used to bypass this effect but the menus remain the same of course. Looking at the mechanics involved (besides the puzzles), one thing that really fascinates me is that almost every Sherlock Holmes game tries to invent some new gameplay element. Don't get me wrong I don't mind designers experimenting with the gameplay but I expect the see the good ones becoming permanent mechanics in the series. For example, the Ripper murder scene investigation method is gone now, which is a pity. There seems to be a dialogue wheel present in the game which serves no purpose whatsoever. Deduction board is still fun and there is a very good puzzle element involved with it. But sadly the game does not use it very often, for reasons unknown to this reviewer. Inventory puzzles are not annoying contrary to the rest of the genre. But pixel hunting nightmares strike once or twice during the game (I encourage gamers to consult a walkthough at these points because they're not worth wasting time over, you should just get on with the story instead). The game would have been a better one without them sure but none of these gets in our way of enjoying the story and marveling at Sherlock’s wit and prowess. Putting aside all these bumps, the game plays well and is long enough to satisfy the average user (15 hours).  Board puzzles are nicely done and interact with the world in a sensible way (as far as these sort of games go).  Watson and Sherlock’s dialogues are smart and funny as always and the delivery is very good, though the pace is a bit off; you get too long pauses between some lines that were obviously meant to be interrupting each other. You are still being provided with lots of documents and papers throughout the game (which is nice), some of which you need to read and understand in order to solve puzzles. Locations look very nice but they aren’t many but the Baker St. flat is there as always. Familiar faces pop up once in a while if you know who’s who. The murders are very gruesome and creative. The game is not very difficult also so in a way it feels like a smooth ride if you can overlook stuff mentioned above. So all in all, Testament of S. Holmes is good follow up to his predecessors and if you’re a fan of the previous games, you should definitely get it. If you like point&click adventures, the story is enough reason to pick this one up. But if you’re new to the genre, don’t start here. Pros: very good story, well designed puzzles, true to its source material, familiar voice acting, long gameplay, Cons: UI looks very old, locations are sparse, some near misses with gameplay mechanicsVerdict: 4/5

												I have mixed feelings about this title...was it bad? no, definitely not...was it good? ... hmm...ok, I liked the story, although a bit too far fetched and somehow clumsy in places, it definitely had the right ingredients and a few well placed plot twists to keep me interested throughout the game... I also liked the puzzles - none of them were impossible to pass and at least some were actually pretty amusing :) ... though in particular, I found the recurring "lockpick" puzzle unnecessary - as simple as it was, I found it more of a nuisance than a pleasant deviation from the storytelling... I couldn't help comparing that to an excellently designed lockpick puzzle from "Still Life" and even the purely manual lockpicking from the new "Fallout" games was more believable than that in TTOSH... I didn't like the "chemistry" puzzles too much either...what I liked most, I think, apart, of course, from the more sophisticated locking mechanisms on various containers as mentioned above, were the deduction puzzles. even though you could theoretically solve them by randomly ticking options, they still actually made you think about how to connect all pieces together...the graphics was pleasant, nothing too fancy but nothing particularly bad either - still looking pretty good though maybe not very sophisticated given its 2012 release date... I liked it...what I didn't like then .... the linearity... yeah, I know, it's neither the first not the last point-and-click that does that but there were a few moments where being very artificially bound to the one location you're in at the moment was particularly jarring...the whole "story read by the creepily-modelled kids in the attic" arc - what purpose did that serve?...the glitches (the game crashed on me more than a couple of times in just less than 20 hours of gameplay and, in one place, almost blocking me from playing further), the simplistic inventory-based puzzles, the place where you played _a_ _dog_ ...all in all, yeah, as I said, I did enjoy this game, it did have a few nice moments and amusing puzzles... but would I recommend it? no, not really .... I don't know... maybe I set my expectations too high but I just simply don't feel it's up to the hopes other recommendations here suggested... and given its price, and provided you haven't already played it, I really think another sleuth-themed title - the "LA Noire" is a much better bargain ... (of course, that's a pretty different kind of beast)

talking to this landlady, and the conversation goes"I'm a medical doctor and I'm here to see a patient who is losing his teeth, it's highly contagious"she replies "leave, or you'll be one losing your teeth"so he says "I'm with the department of health to inspect the neighborhood for (something, I forget)"and she says "something something, get out of here"so he says "I'm a painter, here to paint your portrait"So far, three times I've been wandering around trying to figure out why I can't move forward in the story, and looked in my inventory to see I have three peices of rope, but haven't combined all 3 to make a longer rope, or I have a bottle of water and a dry cloth, but the quest needs a damp cloth... or that you have the wrong item highlighted in the corner of the screen, so while you need to cut something, it's not the knife, it's the clippers, or that you need to pick up the pipe to hit the glass, but you inspected the pipe before inspecting the note, so you didn't pick it up, and after reading the note, you have to go back and inspect the pipe again, this time picking it up, even though nothing in the note had anything to do with the pipe, it just wasn't in the required, pre-determined order.Luckily, half way into the game, after about 3 hours of mindlessly clicking on every blue (luckily they turn green after you've finished the sequence in the correct order, but also turn from blue to green and back to blue if done out of order when you unlock the sequence you should have done them in, which gets frustrating) and an hour or two of puzzles (there's really only about 6 in total, one of them, the roman numeral box, can be done correctly, but not the "correct" correct way, which was also frustrating) they have about a 20 minute cutscene to recap what actually happened in the story up to that point. Which is pretty much necessary, because you're so mindbent on mindless clicking and backtracking (if that's possible never leaving the same place, more just walking in circles to the same objects over and over) that you have no idea how all the broken fragments of the story are supposed to fit together. I completely forgot who the guy I was following was in the third act of the first scene.Even in what I assume to be the final act, which is a stealth mission, sort of, you can't get caught. You can run into view of the guard, and you just get turned around to look for the blue icon you haven't finished. The story is fine, it's pretty bland, but for a sherlock holmes story, it goes exactly how you would imagine. Sadly, you have absolutely no contribution to this story, no matter what you do, how hard you try to succeed or intentionally fail, you just can't. 												The Testament of Sherlock Holmes is a good compromise between old-style adevnture games and new-era 3D adventure games with richer stories and cutscenes. It's also better than its sequel which emphasizes too much on the new-era style.The variety of the puzzles is enjoyable and almost everyone is decently implemented. The good thing is that every puzzle is integrated in the scenario and not here just for the purpose or making your brain working (I do not like point and click games like Myst). The difficulty is also not too high and not too low, decently made overall even if the difficulty does not improve over time.The gameplay is really good if you play on first person mode, OK at third person. I chose the last option because I like viewing my character but sometimes I switched to FP mode because of the limitations of the TP mode. In fact, it's harder to target a location sometimes while in TP mode. Still, it's not horrible to play, just a bit harder. I played it with both gamepad and mouse/keybord and I prefer the first option even if I'm an old PC player.The graphics are OK technically speaking and retranscribe well the londonish atmosphere. English voices (which were impossible to pair with french subtitles - which was not a problem because I understand english - even with the developpers tips for steam version) are really well made, especially Holmes voice which retranscribes well the personality of the character.The narrative part is nice even if some events seem far-fetched like what we can see in spectacular american movies. I enjoyed the whole plot and the narrative which is really above the pack for this type of games (without the sacrifice of the gameplay like in telltale games). The whole story is well critten and I admit I doubted about Holmes loyalty. Maybe the last chapter in the amusement park was a bit disappointing but still good.Finally, this game is really solid. I recommend it strongly to people who enjoy a good mix between narrative and old-style puzzles. Sherlock Holmes games are really the best adventure games series nowadays  even if the last episode orientation is disturbing.

												The Testament of Sherlock Holmes is a hard game to nail down as to whether it is good or bad. So I'll give it the patented "Zacryl: Meh+".There are many moments, particularly in the first 2 acts of the game, where the opportunities to explore a (for a 2012 Indie title) incredibly beautifully-rendered Victorian London are a real treat. And trapsing around 221B Baker Street and looking at all the fun nods to the original stories is a pleasure... for a few minutes. Then the clunky mechanics and occasionally asenine puzzle-solving makes it feel less like a game about Sherlock Holmes, and more like having Sherlock Holmes' name slapped onto a rather dull point-and-click adventure.The voice acting is pretty good, though Watson (whom you hear more of in this game than anyone) was a bit too whiny and nasaly to want to listen to for 10 hours. In all, if you're a big Sherlock Holmes fan like myself, it's definitely worth buying when it goes on sale. The game is wonderful when it pays homage to the original stories and keeps to the established canon. But when things start going off the rails story-wise toward the end, or when the puzzles start just being puzzles for puzzles' sake rather than real mysteries to be solved, it becomes a bit of a chore to muscle through.TL;DR? 6.5/10, Good graphics, decent voices, good fanservice, but clunky and story gets dumb at the end.
